intro: Mauloutchia sambiranensis, commonly known as the Sambiranensis fern, is a rare and endemic species found primarily in the rainforests of Madagascar. It belongs to the family Polypodiaceae and is characterized by its delicate, finely divided fronds that are typically less than 30 centimeters in length. The plant thrives in shaded, moist environments and is often found growing on rocky substrates or in the understory of dense vegetation. Its unique morphology and restricted distribution make it a subject of interest for botanists studying biodiversity in Madagascar. Due to habitat loss, it is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
